column1: #Text=NetCov is an open-source tool that can be used with [Batfish](https://github.com/batfish/batfish) to analyze test coverage for network configurations.
#Text=Given a set of Batfish queries, it analyzes which lines of configurations has/has not been covered.
#Text=The result can be used to assess the rigorousness of the test suite and help discover the blind spots.
#Text=Please refer to our [paper](https://www.usenix.org/conference/nsdi23/presentation/xu) for technical details.
#Text=NetCov is written in Python and can be used in concert with [pybatfish](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/interacting.html), Batfish's Python API.
#Text=NetCov supports coverage tracking for the following [Batfish questions](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/questions.html):

#Text=- Direct inspection of routing tables via [routes](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/routingTables.html#Routes) and [bgpRib](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/routingTables.html#BGP-RIB) questions
#Text=NetCov supports configuration syntax of the following vendors:
#Text=|                    | Interface          | BGP neighbor       | Routing Policy     | Prefix list        | Community list     | As-path list       |

#Text=If you’d like support for additional [vendors](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/supported_devices.html) (which are supported by Batfish but unsupported by NetCov) or currently-unsupported configuration features, let us know via [GitHub issue](https://github.com/UWNetworksLab/netcov/issues).
#Text=We'll try to add support, and it would help if you share a configuration example.
#Text=You may want to use an [anonymizer](https://github.com/intentionet/netconan) before sharing.
#Text=NetCov reports configuration coverage as the percentage of configuration lines that are covered, such as:
#Text=NetCov can also report fine-grained coverage results as colored annotations on source configurations (lines in blue are covered, lines in red are not covered):
#Text=You can find an example of the coverage report [here](https://rawcdn.githack.com/UWNetworksLab/netcov/main/examples/fattree4/coverage/HTML_REPORT/index.html).
#Text=A virtual environment and Python version 3.7 is recommended.
#Text=If you would like to use this feature, install LCOV using Homebrew (MacOS) or apt (Ubuntu):
#Text=It provides a hooked version of pybatfish APIs that automatically tracks coverage during the execution of supported pybatfish questions.
#Text=### Using NetCov for an existing pybatfish script/notebook
#Text=It takes only two simple steps to measure coverage for your existing pybatfish scripts/notebooks.
#Text=For import, replace pybatfish client session with the one provided by NetCov:
#Text=Generate coverage results at the end of your script.
#Text=To print coverage metrics to the console, use `bf.cov.result()`.
#Text=### Use NetCov for a new pybatfish script/notebook
#Text=v=FcBD2LhxqOQ) and an [example](examples/demo.ipynb) to help you get started.
#Text=If you are new to pybatfish, we recommend reading the [pybatfish doc](https://pybatfish.readthedocs.io/en/latest/notebooks/interacting.html) first.
#Text=Sometimes not all information retrieved by Batfish questions are meant to be tested, for example, when you retrieve all RIB entries but only assert on a subset of them.
#Text=To help NetCov model coverage more accurately, you can pause coverage tracking and add tested information use a NetCov API:
#Text=# pause coverage tracking to avoid over-estimation
#Text=# add tested route to coverage trace
#Text=`bf.cov.result()` prints coverage metrics using `logging` module and writes to `stderr` by default.
#Text=To save the coverage report to file, you can customize logger by:
#Text=  author = {Xieyang Xu and Weixin Deng and Ryan Beckett and Ratul Mahajan and David Walker},
#Text=  booktitle = {20th USENIX Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI 23)},
